qas.question: Where is the primary circadian gene located in humans?
Where are these cell groups found in humans?
What would the loss of the SCN cells cause in the sleep-wake rhythm?
What provides information to the SCN?
What special cells in the eyes communicate directly to the SCN cells?
Where is the secondary circadian clocl located?

plausible_answers.text: a pair of distinct groups of cells
complete absence of a regular sleep–wake rhythm

qas.question: What do the SCN cells cause in the sleep-wake rythem?
What do the SCN recieve through the skin?
What does the pupil contain that are directly photosensative?

context: The primary circadian "clock" in mammals is located <b5_0>in the <a0_0>suprachiasmatic nucleus<b5_0/><a0_0/> (or nuclei) (SCN), <b6_0>a pair of distinct groups of cells<b6_0/> located in the <a1_0>hypothalamus<a1_0/>. Destruction of the SCN results in the <a2_0><b7_0>complete absence<a2_0/> of a regular sleep–wake rhythm<b7_0/>. The SCN receives <b8_0>information about illumination<b8_0/> through the <a3_0>eyes<a3_0/>. The retina of the eye contains "classical" photoreceptors ("rods" and "cones"), which are used for conventional vision. But the retina also contains <b9_0>specialized <a4_0>ganglion<a4_0/> cells<b9_0/> that are directly photosensitive, and project directly to the SCN, where they help in the entrainment (synchronization) of this master circadian clock.
